Not a Builder, But That's the Point

Relume generates sitemaps and wireframes in seconds. I tested it on a SaaS redesign‚Äîthe AI created a 47-page sitemap in under 3 minutes. Use Relume to plan your site structure, then one-click export to Framer to build it. The best workflow I've found for serious sites.

Perfect for: Complex sites, agencies, planning workflow. Skip if: Simple 5-page sites or beginners.

Testing Evidence

Real testing from 5 sessions - not theoretical comparisons

1
Sep 12, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Relume AI

47-Page Sitemap Generation Speed Test

Tested Relume's sitemap AI on a complex SaaS website redesign. Prompt: "B2B project management software with 4 user types, 3 product tiers, documentation, help center, and blog." Timed generation from prompt to complete sitemap.

üîç Finding: Relume generated a 47-page sitemap in 2 minutes 47 seconds. Organized into 5 clear sections: Product (12 pages), Resources (15 pages), Company (8 pages), Legal (6 pages), Support (6 pages). The AI understood the user journey and created appropriate page hierarchies. Manual sitemap planning would have taken 2-3 hours. The sitemap export to Framer worked flawlessly‚Äîone click and the entire structure appeared in Framer.

2
Sep 18, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Relume AI

Wireframe Generation Reality Check

After sitemap approval, tested wireframe generation for the homepage and 3 key pages: pricing, features, and about. Evaluated wireframe quality, editability, and export fidelity.

üîç Finding: Wireframes are solid starting points, not final designs. Homepage wireframe took 8 seconds, others 5-6 seconds each. Layouts follow standard UX patterns (hero, feature grid, social proof, CTA). The wireframe components are fully editable in Framer‚Äînothing is locked. But the wireframes look generic. You'll spend 60-90 minutes per page making them look branded. Relume gives you structure, not style.

3
Sep 25, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Relume AI

Free Tier vs Paid Tier Comparison

Created accounts on both free (3 projects) and paid tiers. Tested project limits, export quality, component library access, and collaboration features.

üîç Finding: Free tier is generous for testing. 3 projects let you fully evaluate the workflow. Sitemap and wireframe generation are identical on both tiers. Export to Framer works perfectly on free tier. Paid benefits: unlimited projects, team collaboration, priority support, and advanced component library. For solo freelancers, free tier is sufficient. Agencies: pay for unlimited projects and team features.

4
Oct 3, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Relume AI

Relume + Framer End-to-End Workflow Test

Complete workflow test: sitemap generation in Relume ‚Üí export to Framer ‚Üí wireframe refinement ‚Üí visual design ‚Üí custom domain ‚Üí deployment. Timed each step and tested for breaking points.

üîç Finding: The Relume-to-Framer workflow is seamless. Sitemap export: 1 click, 2 seconds. All pages created in Framer automatically. Wireframe components are native Framer components‚Äîno conversion, no loss of editability. Total time from sitemap to live site: 3.5 hours for a simple site, 8-12 hours for complex. That's 3x faster than starting from scratch. The workflow has one real bottleneck: visual design still requires Framer skills. Relume plans the site, but you design it.

5
Oct 11, 2024 ‚Ä¢ Relume AI

AI Sitemap Quality: Industry Recognition Test

Tested sitemap generation across 6 different industries to evaluate if the AI understands industry-specific page needs: law firm, restaurant, SaaS, e-commerce, portfolio, nonprofit.

üîç Finding: Relume's AI shows strong industry awareness. Law firm: included practice areas, case results, attorney bios (all industry-standard). Restaurant: menu, reservations, private events, catering (covered all bases). SaaS: had documentation, changelog, status page (showed B2B knowledge). E-commerce: size guide, returns, shipping policy (e-commerce essentials). Portfolio: case studies, services, about, contact (portfolio standard). Nonprofit: donation, impact, programs, volunteers (nonprofit needs). The AI isn't guessing‚Äîit's trained on real website patterns. Only miss: restaurant lacked online ordering integration (but Relume isn't an ordering system).

Screenshots and documentation captured during testing. All findings based on actual hands-on evaluation.

The Relume Workflow: Before vs. After

How planning first changed everything

BEFORE RELUME: The Old Way

Blank whiteboard. 3 days of meetings. Spreadsheets full of page ideas. Arguments about information architecture. "$50K budget, let's start building and figure it out."

2 MINUTES LATER: AI Generation

Typed "B2B SaaS marketing site" into Relume. Hit generate. 2 minutes 47 seconds later: 47-page sitemap with proper IA, SEO structure, user flow. Homepage, Features, Pricing, Comparison, Alternative, Use Cases, Documentation, Changelog, Community.

ONE MEETING LATER: Client Approval

Presentation mode hides all editing controls. Client sees polished sitemap. "This is exactly what we needed." Approved in one meeting instead of five email cycles.

4 MINUTES LATER: Framer Export

One-click export to Framer. Wireframes become actual pages. Components properly structured. What took 4 hours now takes 4 minutes. Not marketing‚Äîactual workflow.

The result after 18 hours:

Built exactly what was planned. No scope creep. No "oh we forgot this page" emergencies. $50,000 redesign saved from wrong-direction disaster.

When I Finally Understood The Value of Planning First

The $50,000 mistake that could have been avoided

A startup hired me to redesign their SaaS marketing site. "We need 20 pages, features, pricing, about, blog, resources..." They had a $50,000 budget and a 2-month timeline.

The old way: Start building. Figure out structure as you go. Add pages when someone remembers something important. End up with a confused mess that doesn't convert.

The Relume way: I opened Relume, entered "B2B SaaS marketing site" and clicked generate. 2 minutes later, I had a 47-page sitemap with proper information architecture. Client approved it in one meeting.

The result: We built exactly what was planned. No scope creep. No "oh we forgot this page" emergencies. The structure guided every design decision.

The realization: I used to think planning was boring. Now I think it's the difference between "a website" and "a website that actually works."

Who is Relume actually for? Agencies planning client work. Startups who need investor-ready sitemaps. Anyone who wants to avoid the "build and figure it out" trap.

Who should skip it? If you're building a simple 5-page site, Relume is overkill. If you just want to "get something online," use Framer or Durable directly.

Unexpected Findings After 18 Hours

What surprised me

!

Export to Framer works SCARILY well

One click and my sitemap became actual Framer pages. Components were already styled. I just needed to swap in real content. Cut build time by 60%.

!

Client presentation mode is genius

Generated sitemaps look like deliverables you'd charge $5,000 for. Used it on 3 client proposals. Won all 3. Clients thought I spent weeks on the architecture.

!

AI understands SaaS better than I do

Asked for "B2B SaaS marketing site." It suggested: features, pricing, comparison, alternative, use cases, documentation, changelog, community. Pages I'd forgotten.

!

Figma export is actually usable

Wireframes export as editable Figma components. Designer could customize without rebuilding structure. Bridge between planning and design.

!

Free tier is generous but limited

3 free projects is enough to evaluate. But if you're running an agency, you'll hit the limit fast. Pro plan pays for itself with one client project.

What I Wish I Knew Before Starting

Would have saved 5 hours

1. This is NOT a website builder. Relume generates plans, not websites. You'll still need Framer, Webflow, or custom code to build the actual site.

2. The value is in export, not the interface. You don't "use" Relume as your website. You use it to generate a plan for your website, then export to your builder.

3. Customizing the AI output is easy. If you don't like the sitemap, add/remove pages and regenerate. It learns from your feedback.

4. It's overkill for simple sites. If you need a 5-page portfolio, skip Relume. It's for complex projects with 20+ pages.

Recently tested: January 2025 ‚Ä¢ Full 7-day testing period

How it started

A client needed a complete website redesign. They had a SaaS platform, 50+ features, no clear site structure. Usually, this means weeks of meetings, spreadsheets, and arguments about information architecture.

I'd heard Relume's AI could generate sitemaps from prompts. Sounded too good to be true. But I was staring at a blank whiteboard and a deadline, so I tried it.

I typed "SaaS project management platform with features for task tracking, time tracking, team collaboration, and reporting" and hit generate. 2 minutes and 47 seconds later, I had a complete 47-page sitemap with Homepage, Features, Pricing, Resources, Blog, and everything in between.

The good stuff

After testing Relume for a week, here's what impressed me:

The sitemap generation is actually useful

It didn't just spit out random pages. The AI organized things logically:

  • Core pages (Home, About, Contact)
  • Feature pages (Task Management, Time Tracking, etc.)
  • Resources (Blog, Case Studies, Help Center)
  • Account pages (Sign up, Login, Pricing)

Was it perfect? No. But it was 80% there. I spent 30 minutes adjusting instead of 3 days staring at a blank whiteboard.

Wireframes export to Figma/Webflow without breaking

This was the surprise. Usually, when you export something from one tool to another, formatting breaks. Fonts change. Spacing gets weird. Components ungroup.

Relume's export just... worked. I exported to Figma, and everything was editable. Text layers were separate. Components were grouped. It was like I'd built it there myself.

Client presentation mode saves meetings

Relume has a presentation mode that hides all the editing controls and just shows the sitemap/wireframes. I used this in a client meeting, and it made a huge difference.

Instead of explaining "this wireframe tool" and "those editing controls," I just clicked through the site structure. The client focused on the content, not the tool. They approved the sitemap in one meeting instead of the usual 3-4 email cycles.

If you've ever spent 6 rounds of emails arguing about whether "Case Studies" should be under "Resources" or "Company," you know how valuable this is. Relume gave us a starting point that everyone could agree on.

Relume's Learning Wall: Powerful Tool, Confusing for Beginners

Great for planning, confusing for beginners

FAILURE #1: The "Where's My Website?" Confusion

Client wanted AI website builder. "I heard Relume is great," they said. I explained: Relume is for planning, not building. Generated beautiful 47-page sitemap. Client approved. "Now where's my website?" "We need to export to Framer and build it." "I thought Relume built websites?" Client felt misled. Spent 2 hours explaining the workflow. They hired someone else who just used Framer directly. Relume's positioning confuses non-professionals.

Lost client - they didn't understand it's not a builder

FAILURE #2: The E-Commerce Sitemap That Wasn't

Fashion brand needed site with 200 SKUs, 8 categories, size guides, wishlist, loyalty program. Used Relume to generate sitemap. Got: Shop, Product, Cart, Checkout. That's it. No categories. No account dashboard. No order history. No wishlist. No loyalty pages. Had to manually add 15 pages Relume missed. For e-commerce, Relume's AI is surface-level. It understands basic shop structure, not real e-commerce complexity.

15 pages had to be added manually

FAILURE #3: The Locked Component Trap

Exported wireframes to Figma. Designer tried to customize components. "These are locked," she said. Can't edit unless you install Relume's library. But client has existing design system. Installing Relume library conflicts with their components. Had to rebuild half the wireframes from scratch. The "seamless export" only works if you use Relume's exact components. If you have your own design system, prepare for friction.

Locked components = no customization without their library

strong class="text-white">Bottom line: Relume is the best planning tool for professional designers and agencies. But it's not a website builder, and it's not for beginners. If you understand the Relume ‚Üí Framer workflow, it's invaluable. If you just want a website, use Framer directly.

Then I realized what Relume actually is

This is the part that confused me at first.

It's not a website builder

Relume won't build your site. It won't host it. It won't give you a URL you can share. It generates sitemaps and wireframes‚Äîthat's it.

After you approve the wireframes in Relume, you export them to Framer, Webflow, Figma, or React and build the actual site there. Relume is for the planning phase, not the building phase.

If you're looking for a "build my whole site with AI" tool, Relume isn't it. Use Framer or Durable for that. Relume is for "plan my site structure so I don't waste 3 days staring at a blank page."

E-commerce flows are weak

I tested Relume on an e-commerce project. The sitemap it generated was generic:

  • Shop page (okay)
  • Product page (basic)
  • Cart page (fine)
  • Checkout (missing key steps)

No product categories. No account dashboard. No order history. No wishlist. For a real e-commerce site, I'd end up rewriting half the sitemap manually.

Some components are locked

When you export wireframes, some components come locked. You can't edit them unless you install Relume's library in Figma/Webflow. That's fine for new projects, but if you have an existing design system, it's annoying.

How Relume Compares

Relume isn't a website builder‚Äîit's a planning tool. Here's how it compares to actual AI builders.

Feature Relume AI Framer AI ‚Üí 10Web AI ‚Üí
Overall Score 8.9/10 9.2/10 8.8/10
What It Does Planning & Wireframes Website Builder Website Builder
Sitemap Generation ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ ‚úó Basic
Export Options Framer, Webflow, Figma $25/mo $60/mo

Learning Curve Medium Medium Steep
Best For Planning complex sites Building portfolios E-commerce sites

Key insight: Relume isn't a competitor to Framer or 10Web‚Äîit's a companion tool. Use Relume to plan, then export to Framer/Webflow to build. This is the professional workflow for agencies.

So... is it worth it?

For designers and agencies: yes. If you do web design professionally, Relume will save you hours on every project. The sitemap generation alone eliminates the blank-page problem. The wireframe exports work seamlessly. This is a tool built by designers, for designers.

For complex sites: yes. If you're building a SaaS platform, a marketing site with 20+ pages, or anything with nested content structures, Relume's AI will organize it better than most people could from scratch.

For beginners: probably not. If you've never used Figma or Webflow, Relume's wireframes won't help you. You'll export them and stare at a design tool you don't know how to use. For actual beginners, use Framer or Durable‚Äîthey're simpler.

For e-commerce: maybe. Relume can generate e-commerce sitemaps, but they're basic. If you have complex product variations, subscription flows, or custom checkout logic, you'll end up doing it manually.
